articles.author: Times
articles.summary: Climate change poses a serious threat to maritime archaeology. Rising sea temperatures, rampant ocean acidification, deep sea mining, cable laying, pipeline projects, and even small-scale pleasure craft anchoring all pose a threat to humanity's shared maritime history. The tiniest changes in environment can destroy otherwise protected objects.

articles.title: Commentary: Musings by Ed Anderson — Have you noticed any of these changes?

articles.summary: Humans are causing changes in nature. In 20 years, the U.S. has lost 22% of its butterflies. Grassland birds have declined by 53%. There are few white-throated sparrows, no white-capped chickadees and even fewer whip-poor-wills. The decline of the monarch is an example. Habitat is the key to any specie's success.

articles.title: The Caribbean must speak with one voice

She is worried about the decline in US aid to the region and the impact on climate change. Communities in Yorkshire are set to benefit.

The 2024 Aussie Bird Count, conducted by BirdLife Australia, recorded 4.1 million bird sightings across the week-long event in October. More than 57,000 participants took part in the count. The data is being used to drive BirdLife's conservation strategy to stop bird extinctions by 2032 and halt overall decline in bird species population by 2050.

articles.title: Earth's axis tilted by 31.5 inches due to THIS reason, India among top contributors to shocking global shift
articles.author: Pravrajya Suruchi
articles.summary: In less than 20 years, the Earth's axis has shifted by 31.5 inches (80 cm) due to human activities. People pumped 2,150 gigatons of groundwater from underground reservoirs between 1993 and 2010. The Earth's rotational pole has moved eastward by 4.36 cm every year due to this water loss. Western North America and northwestern India are key regions affected by groundwater loss.

articles.title: Most of Chile sets clocks backwards during the weekend
articles.summary: Chile went back to winter time on Sunday. Clocks in most of the country's territory were set back one hour to 23:00 on Saturday, April 5. The Aysén del General Carlos Ibáñez del Campo and Magallanes have retained daylight saving time (UTC-3). Easter Island and Salas y Gómez Island adjusted their clocks one hour at 22:00 local time on April 5, aligning with the mainland's winter time shift.

articles.summary: The global community continues to grapple with the escalating effects of climate change. Despite regular gatherings and an ever-expanding catalogue of pledges, the climate crisis intensifies. Education is central to this shift. Education must become a vehicle for social and emotional learning, environmental ethics and sustainability skills. Children and youth stand at the heart of this behavioural transformation.

Edun made this disclosure with the Director-General of the Nigeria Climate Change Council (NCCC), Nkiruka Madueke, on Monday in Abuja. They discussed the urgency of unlocking the underutilised CCF to support projects that will enable the implementation of Nigeria's net-zero emissions target and third generation Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs).

The Chacaltaya glacier in the Andes had disappeared entirely by 2009. Venezuela lost its last glacier, La Corona, in 2023. According to a global forecast, if global temperatures rise by 4 degrees Celsius by 2100, over 80 percent of the world's glaciers could be lost.

articles.title: This melting globe in Gurgaon is the climate wake-up call we all need
articles.author: Manasvi Pote
articles.summary: Aakash Ranison's Below2° is a five-foot-long melting globe made from 1,000 repurposed golf balls, hand-painted by children, and a special wax blend that begins to melt at 53°C. The core of the sculpture softens, sags, and slowly disintegrates as the temperature rises, mirroring the fragile state of our planet. The artwork has 14 endangered species surrounding it.
